item.label: Cerebral gyri, Cingulate
item.name: Cingulate gyrus
item.description: The cingulate gyrus is the region of the cerebral cortex that arcs above the corpus callosum on the medial aspect of the hemisphere. Along with the parahippocampal gyrus to which it is connected by the isthmus of the cingulate gyrus, posterior to the splenium of the corpus callosum, it is considered to be the "Limbic lobe" of the brain.

item.label: Cerebral fissures, Lateral
item.name: Lateral fissure
item.description: The lateral fissure or sulcus is AKA the Sylvian fissure. It is a long, deep sulcus on the lateral aspect of each cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.  The main portion of the fissure is sometimes referred to as the posterior ramus.  Anteriorly, the fissure branches to subdivide the inferior frontal gyrus; anterior horizontal and anterior ascending rami delineate the orbital, triangular and opercular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus.  The cortex known as the insula is located deep within this sulcus and the transverse temporal gyri (auditory cortex) is located on the temporal lobe aspect of the fissure.

item.label: Commissure, Corpus callosum
item.name: Corpus callosum
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Hippocampal formation
item.name: Hippocampal formation
item.description: The hippocampus is AKA the hippocampal formation. It is an area of cerebral cortex rolled up inside the medial aspect of the temporal lobe. It is part of the limbic system and functions in the consolidation of new memories of facts and events. It has three subdivisions: the hippocampus proper (Ammon's horn), the dentate gyrus, and the subiculum. The fornix carries the primary output from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal area and hypothalamus.

item.label: Fornix
item.name: Fornix
item.description: The fornix is a compact bundle of axons, primarily efferents from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal nuclei and hypothalamus. Parts of the fornix from the hippocampus and beyond are the fimbria, crus, body and column.

item.label: Descending motor tracts
item.name: Descending Tracts
item.description: These descending motor tracts originate in the cerebral cortex and then travel through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, the cerebral crus of the midbrain, the basilar portion of the pons and the pyramids of the medulla.  Sometimes this group of tracts is referred to as the pyramidal tract or system.  It includes the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tracts.  The corticopontine fibers terminate at the level of the pons; therefore, the pyramids contain only corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers while only the corticospinal fibers continue into the spinal cord.  There are other subcortical descending motor tracts (reticulospinal and vestibulospinal) that originate in the reticular formation and vestibular nuclei of the brain stem.

item.label: Internal capsule, Posterior limb
item.name: Internal capsule
item.description: The internal capsule is a thick fiber bundle that is the primary route of communication between the cerebral cortex and other CNS structures. It includes the thalamocortical, corticothalamic, corticospinal, corticobulbar, etc. tracts. It consists of an anterior limb, genu and posterior limb that form a "V" shape as seen in mid-level horizontal or axial sections.   The lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus) is located laterally inside the "V" and the caudate nucleus and thalamus are located medially.

item.label: Caudate nucleus
item.name: Caudate nucleus
item.description: The caudate nucleus is the medial portion of the striatum. It consists of a large head that bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle, a body that narrows and curves along the body of the lateral ventricle and a tail that continues through the atrium or trigone of the lateral ventricle and into the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. Principal connections are with the prefrontal and other association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Putamen
item.name: Putamen
item.description: The putamen is the large lateral component of the lentiform nucleus, located lateral to the globus pallidus and the internal capsule. With the caudate nucleus, it is known as the striatum. Portion of the striatum most involved in the motor function of the basal ganglia. Receives afferents from motor and somatosensory cerebral cortex, substantia nigra and centromedian nucleus of the thalamus; sents efferents to globus pallidus.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Medial cell mass
item.name: Medial cell mass
item.description: The thalamus (dorsal thalamus) is divided into medial and lateral groups of nuclei by the internal medullary lamina (a thin, curved sheet of myelinated nerve fibers).  The medial group of nuclei is much smaller in mass than the lateral group. The medial group is composed primarily of the dorsomedial (or mediodorsal) nucleus.

item.label: Internal medullary lamina
item.name: Int medullary lamina
item.description: The internal medullary lamina of the thalamus is a thin layer of nerve fibers located within the substance of the thalamus that partially separates the thalamus into medial and lateral divisions. Anteriorly, it encloses the anterior thalamic nuclei. The centromedian and parafascicular nuclei are contained within the lamina.

item.label: Lateral cell mass
item.name: Lateral cell mass
item.description: The thalamus (dorsal thalamus) is divided into medial and lateral groups of nuclei by the internal medullary lamina (a thin, curved sheet of myelinated nerve fibers).  The lateral group of nuclei composes the bulk of the thalamus.  It includes the following nuclei:  lateral dorsal, lateral posterior, pulvinar, ventral anterior, ventral lateral, ventral posterior, lateral geniculate, medial geniculate.

item.label: External medullary lamina
item.name: Ext medullary lamina
item.description: The external medullary lamina of the thalamus is a thin layer of nerve fibers located lateral to the thalamus and medial to the reticular nucleus of the thalamus and posterior limb of the internal capsule. Note: Do not confuse with the external medullary lamina that is located between the globus pallidus and putamen.

item.label: Reticular nucleus
item.name: Reticular nucleus
item.description: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus is a thin shell of neurons surrounding the ventral and lateral aspect of the thalamus. It is sandwiched between the internal capsule and the external medullary lamina of the thalamus. It has no projections to cerebral cortex. It receives afferents from the thalamus and cerebral cortex and sends GABAergic efferents back to the thalamus.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic tract
item.name: Optic tract
item.description: The Optic tract consists of optic nerve axons that serve the contralateral visual field.  These axons originate in the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina and terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus as well as the pretectal area.

item.label: Subthalamic nucleus
item.name: Subthalamic nucleus
item.description: The subthalamic nucleus is a bi-convex lens-shaped nucleus located just medial and superior to the junction of the internal capsule and crus cerebri. The subthalamic nucleus is part of an indirect route through the basal ganglia whereby it receives input from the external segment of the globus pallidus and returns it output to the internal segment of the globus pallidus. Damage to the subthalamic nucleus produces hemiballismus on the contralateral side of the body.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Red nucleus
item.name: Red nucleus
item.description: The red nucleus is a large, round nucleus in the tegmentum of the midbrain that appears pink or red on freshly-sectioned tissue. It is involved with motor control via its connections with the cerebellum. It receives contralateral input from both the dentate and interposed deep cerebellar nuclei; its primary output in the human is to the ipsilateral inferior olivary nucleus via the central tegmental tract. Since the inferior olivary nucleus projects to contralateral cerebellum, the red nucleus is part of a feedback loop to the cerebellum. While the red nucleus gives origin to a significant rubrospinal tract in non-human species, this tract appears to be of limited extent and importance in humans.

item.label: Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Cerebral crus
item.name: Cerebral crus
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Interpeduncular fossa
item.name: Interpeduncular fossa
item.description: The interpeduncular fossa is the space between the cerebral peduncles on the ventral surface of the midbrain.

item.label: Pons, basilar
item.name: Pons (basilar)
item.description: The basilar pons is AKA the basal pons. It is the ventral portion of the pons that includes the following important elements that are primarily involved in motor control: corticospinal, corticobulbar, corticospinal and pontocerebellar tracts plus the pontine nuclei. Thus, it serves as a conduit for descending motor pathways from cerebral cortex to the pons, medulla and spinal cord. In addition, it connects the cerebral cortex with the cerebellum via synapses of the corticopontine fibers on pontine nuclei that then give origin to the pontocerebellar fibers which terminate in cerebellum.

item.label: Corticospinal, etc. tracts
item.name: Pyramidal pathway
item.description: These descending motor tracts originate in the cerebral cortex and then travel through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, the cerebral crus of the midbrain, the basilar portion of the pons and the pyramids of the medulla.  Sometimes this group of tracts is referred to as the pyramidal tract or system.  It includes the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tracts.  The corticopontine fibers terminate at the level of the pons; therefore, the pyramids contain only corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers while only the corticospinal fibers continue into the spinal cord.  There are other subcortical descending motor tracts (reticulospinal and vestibulospinal) that originate in the reticular formation and vestibular nuclei of the brain stem.

item.label: Trigeminal nerves
item.name: Trigeminal nerve
item.description: The fifth or trigeminal cranial nerve enters/exits the brain stem through the basilar portion of the pons. It provides somatosensory innervation to the head via its ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular roots which converge upon the trigeminal ganglion and then form a massive sensory root entering the brainstem. It provides motor innervation to the muscles derived from the first branchial arch (muscles of mastication, tensor tympani, anterior belly of diagastric, tensor veli palatini and mylohyoid) via a smaller motor root that distributes with the mandibular sensory root.

item.label: Abducens nerves
item.name: Abducens nerve
item.description: The abducens nerve is the sixth cranial nerve.  It innervates the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle. It exits the brain stem anteriorly at the pontomedullary junction.

item.label: Facial nerves
item.name: Facial nerve
item.description: The facial or seventh cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem in the cerebellopontine angle with the vestibulocochlear nerve. The most important sensory component carries taste from the anterior 2/3rds of the tongue; motor components innervate the skeletal muscles of facial expression, stapedius, etc. as well as provide the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that control secretion of the submandibular, sublingual and lacrimal glands.

item.label: Vestibulocochlear nerves
item.name: Vestibulocochlear nerve
item.description: The vestibulocochlear nerve is AKA the statoacoustic nerve. This eighth cranial nerve enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. It carries information from the hair cell receptors in the organ of Corti of the cochlear duct as well as from the vestibular organs (cristae of the semicircular ducts and maculae of the utricle and saccule of the inner ear).

item.label: Medulla
item.name: Medulla
item.description: The medulla is AKA the medulla oblongata. The most caudal aspect of the brain stem, it is located between the pons and spinal cord. It contains structures vital to survival such as cardiovascular and respiratory centers, as well as many cranial nerve nuclei. The major ascending and descending tracts travel through it between the spinal cord and higher centers. It originates developmentally from the myelencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Pyramid
item.name: Pyramid
item.description: The pyramid is a large fiber bundle located on the medial and ventral aspect of the medulla. It consists of corticospinal (and some corticobulbar) fibers that originate in the ipsilateral cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus and elsewhere). These upper motor neuron fibers terminate on lower motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord (corticospinal) and on cranial nerve motor neurons in the medulla (corticobulbar). Often referred to as the pyramidal tract.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Lateral ventricle
item.name: Lateral ventricle
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.

item.label: Third ventricle
item.name: Third ventricle
item.description: The third ventricle is a single, narrow, vertically-oriented portion of the ventricular system.  It is located between the two halves of the thalamus and hypothalamus.
